input:

19:06 Event: Clearance by Bayern Munich
19:58 Event: Shots on target by Bayern Munich
20:05 Caption: Unbelievable! Thomas Muller (Bayern Munich) wastes a huge scoring opportunity! He finds himself unmarked right in front of goal and fires in a first-time shot. Ederson pulls off one of the best saves of his career and stops the effort from hitting the net.

22:13 Caption: The goalkeeper punched the ball away after Nicolas Gaitan (Benfica) took the corner.

47:40 Caption: There will be nothing more to see in the first half. The whistle blowing of Szymon Marciniak has ended it.
47:59 Caption: Well, it hasn't been the most exciting game in the world but there has been some nice football on display. We hope that the second period will bring more action. Bayern Munich dominated the opening period and easily created the most chances. The home side are keeping possession of the ball with some short passes, while the visitors are waiting to open up their defence and hit them swiftly on the break.

49:58 Caption: Nothing more will happen in this game as the referee blows for full time.
49:59 Caption: We were witnesses to an uneventful game without many stirring moments. There is definitely room for improvement in future games. Bayern Munich were dominant and more threatening of the two sides. It was a fairly one-sided match. Short passing and possession was the style of the home side, while the visiting side tried to hit their opposition on the break.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a highly anticipated UEFA Champions League encounter, Bayern Munich hosted Benfica at the Allianz Arena. The match promised excitement from the outset, given Bayern Munich's dominance in European football and Benfica’s persistent knack for causing upsets. As the whistle blew, Benfica took the kick-off, marking the beginning of an intense football showdown.

The game began with immediate physicality, as Benfica committed a foul only 15 seconds after kick-off. Bayern Munich quickly capitalized on the situation and were awarded an indirect free-kick. For the next minute, both teams tried to establish control, but an early clearance by Benfica did little to ease their troubles.

Surprisingly, it took Bayern Munich less than two minutes to strike gold. Bayern's goal came at the 1:48 mark, and the Allianz Arena erupted in celebration. This early goal shifted the momentum entirely in Bayern Munich’s favor, and they were clearly driven to build on their lead.

Benfica restarted the game and tried to find their rhythm, but it was challenging against Bayern’s relentless pressure. By the fourth minute, Benfica found themselves on the wrong side of an offside call, handing the ball back to Bayern once again. Following this, Bayern Munich were awarded an indirect free kick after another lackluster attempt by Benfica.

Seconds turned into minutes with ball possession shifting between clears, throw-ins, and corner kicks. Bayern Munich repeatedly tried to break through Benfica’s defense, but clearances and offsides marred their efforts. The dynamic playstyle of Bayern was evident; their strategy involved pressurizing Benfica’s backline continuously.

At the 9:26 mark, Bayern Munich managed to get a shot on target, but it wasn’t enough to elicit a serious threat. Each team's defense, however, was holding up impressively, making for a tactical masterclass. By the tenth minute, Bayern's attack was temporarily stunted by an offside flag against Jonas, indicating that Benfica was slowly finding discipline in their defensive line.

The first fifteen minutes saw Bayern Munich’s supreme tactical plays and possession-based football prevailing. Notably, they were awarded multiple corners and tried to muster more intensive attacks. During these attempts, Douglas Costa and Franck Ribery were pivotal in creating opportunities, but Benfica’s Ederson stood like a wall in goal, denying them constantly.

Franck Ribery’s engagement at the 14:31 mark was crucial but slightly off the mark, leading to a missed shot. However, Bayern's persistence was commendable. Philipp Lahm provided another half-chance, probing Benfica’s defense basin at 15:42, but even that was snuffed out by Ederson, who appeared in fine form despite previous knocks.

By the 18th minute, a perfect cross from the wing nearly shifted play in Benfica's favor with a bullet header from Konstantinos Mitroglou. Though his attempt went wide, it served as a reminder to Bayern Munich that Benfica was not a team to be underestimated. Bayern Munich narrowly escaped and continued their offensive strategies, with Thomas Muller engineering another glorious but missed opportunity at the 20:05 mark. Benito not only kept Bayern’s at bay but also absorbed much of their momentum.

As the match ticked past the 21st minute, fouls became frequent with Bayern accruing a yellow card. Franck Ribery was cautioned for his rough tackle, signaling rising tensions on the field. Benfica’s attempts to equalize were resilient but lacked precision, characterized by misaligned shots and failed passes. By the 30-minute mark, it became apparent that Bayern’s defense—led by Juan Bernat and company—were thoroughly vigilant.

The first half also highlighted multiple slightly aggressive challenges that led to indirect free-kicks. Players like Thiago Alcantara and Nicolas Gaitan tried leveraging these set pieces, but neither team could capitalize.

As the first half came to a close, Bayern had established their dominance with sharp, short passes and ball retention, effectively sidelining Benfica’s counter-attacks. Another yellow card, this time for Juan Bernat due to a tough tackle, confirmed Bayern's aggressive stance. The half ended without much excitement concerning goals but surely demonstrated Bayern’s tactical superiority.

The second half rekindled hopes for Benfica as they kicked off, aiming for some match-altering maneuvers. The initial few minutes involved standard engagements, with Bayern almost scoring through a dangerous low pass by Juan Bernat which was cut out efficiently. Bayern had their opportunities flagged offside multiple times, the first notable instance being a call against Franck Ribery at the 2:38 mark and another involving Robert Lewandowski at the 4:05 mark.

Ljubomir Fejsa’s rough challenge earned Benfica one of their early second-half fouls, reiterating their physical strategy. Bayern Munich maintained possession and control, further testing Benfica’s defensive resolve. Shots on target by Bayern, particularly from players like Douglas Costa, continuously pressed Ederson, who remained ever-alert.

The highlight for Benfica arose around the 11:14 mark when Manuel Neuer made a thrilling save to deny Jonas. This was a pivotal moment that might have turned the tide had it found the back of the net. By the 12:35 mark, tensions heightened as Jonas received a yellow card for a tackle, ensuring he would miss the subsequent game, a significant blow for Benfica’s squad dynamics.

Substitutions followed with Bayern bringing on Javi Martinez and later Kingsley Coman for a fresh attacking impetus. Benfica's Victor Lindelof’s rough challenge earned him a yellow card, continuing the theme of vigorous, sometimes overly aggressive play.

As Benfica pushed forward, the 18th minute saw Jonas having back-to-back opportunities, creating nervous moments for Bayern fans as his shots were brilliantly blocked or narrowly missed. The sequence of clearances and defensive resilience spoke volumes of Bayern's defensive strength.

The minutes between the 19th and the 25th saw common patterns—offsides, fouls, and replacements, reflecting a match that thrived more on tactical gambles than fluid football. The penalty box remained well-guarded, ensuring that quick breakaways or setups like those attempted by Thomas Muller at 23:16 didn’t yield results.

As the game progressed towards the 29-minute mark, Bayern Munich’s substitutions, especially bringing on players like Mario Gotze, injected some creativity. Yet, the play remained fragmented with constant interceptions and set-piece woes.

Benfica’s own substitutions didn’t significantly alter match dynamics but narratively added to the strategic layer. Substitutes like Raul Jimenez and later Eduardo Salvio tried molding different formations but didn’t pierce Bayern’s shields.

Concluding the game, Bayern exhibited classic control—cescaping attempts by Benfica, efficiently managing possessions with short passing bursts, and creating numerous yet unconverted opportunities. Franck Ribery, even in the dying minutes, remained instrumental in Bayern's pursuits. Notably, his seamless dribbles and threatening crosses were thrilling efforts but always marginally fell short.

By injury time, both sides appeared weary but ever determined. Bayern Munich’s slight offensive pushes siphoned off any last-minute opportunities from Benfica. Amidst the overlaps of clearances, and nuanced offside calls, Bayern held their earthen fort.

The final whistle at 49:58 marked the end of an eloquent yet tactical match dominated by Bayern Munich. Their 1-0 victory epitomized a blend of early decisiveness followed by astoundingly cohesive football. For Benfica, the game was a stirring educational bout, underscoring the essence of European competition—a blend of resilience and tactical prudence.

The game, albeit studded with chances and skilled maneuvers, might not be wholly remembered for explosive goal-laden highlights but surely a case study on football’s tactical and defensive mechanics. Bayern’s ability to dictate match pace without yielding defensive weaknesses showcased why they remain formidable on Europe's grand stages. For both sides, lessons aplenty were gleaned, laying foundations for forthcoming fixtures.
